designConcept: Tune Crafter is an innovative application that allows DJs, Producers, Artists and Curious people to create new beats and sounds using hand gestures, without having to know how to use professional and complicated tools.

leftBubbleDescriptions.title: Tech stack
leftBubbleDescriptions.description: We used Vite.js and React.js with Typescript and Node.js. Gesture recognition used the Mediapipe library and speech recognition used the Webkit library.

rightBubbleDescriptions.title: Performace Tracking
rightBubbleDescriptions.description: Google Analytics is integrated into the website to evaluate performance and analyse user behaviour and demographic information, enabling informed decisions to be made to improve the user experience.

designConcept: EnviroShare addresses the problem of avoiding costly one-off purchases by allowing users to borrow items they do not currently own but may need for a short period of time. This inventive solution promotes a more sustainable and economical use of resources.

leftBubbleDescriptions.title: Users study
leftBubbleDescriptions.description: First, we defined a problem using personas and a current scenario. We used UI concepts to create a mood board and experimented with Jake Knapp's sprint method to quickly iterate on the prototype.

leftBubbleDescriptions.title: Prototyping and Testing
leftBubbleDescriptions.description: We created Hi-Fi Figma prototypes and added interactions. We then tested the prototypes to identify problematic interactions, and then did a second iteration with the improvements.

rightBubbleDescriptions.title: Results
rightBubbleDescriptions.description: We used the 5-second test and the UEQ test, which gave us an overview of the design's performance.

designConcept: Digital Nomads is a platform that connects users with like-minded professionals and helps them find ideal workspaces. The platform encourages collaboration, enabling individuals to build relationships and work together towards common goals.
titleDetails: Rely on user feedback to improve

leftBubbleDescriptions.title: Users Interviews
leftBubbleDescriptions.description: Our initial task was to conduct 15 users interviews and observations in work cafes around Madrid to better comprehend the behaviors and needs of our users.

leftBubbleDescriptions.title: User Profiles: Student, Coorporate worker and Freelancer
leftBubbleDescriptions.description: Our research showed that the primary focus for freelancers and corporate workers is to interact or collaborate with others on specific projects related to their field of work. Meanwhile, for students, the primary focus is obtaining information on where others work or study and having the ability to organize study groups.

rightBubbleDescriptions.title: Usability Testing
rightBubbleDescriptions.description: Two different low-fidelity prototypes were developed to identify the most efficient design. We tested the usability of both low-fidelity prototypes with 15 participants and created two tasks for them to complete without guidance, encouraging them to find their own solutions.

rightBubbleDescriptions.title: HiFi Evaluation
rightBubbleDescriptions.description: We created an HiFi version for Android of the best performing prototype and tested it with 16 participants and collected data on their effectiveness and efficiency.

rightBubbleDescriptions.title: Results
rightBubbleDescriptions.description: The project concluded with a presentation of our work and potential design improvements for the future.

designConcept: Momentus is a mobile application that allows international students to find places and opportunities to meet like-minded people and meet new people with similar interests to build new relationships and avoid loneliness.

leftBubbleDescriptions.title: Interviews coding
leftBubbleDescriptions.description: To understand the needs of international students, we first conducted user interviews and observations. We analysed the data by coding the relevant parts of the text and assessed the reliability and validity of all the data collected.

rightBubbleDescriptions.title: Design Methods
rightBubbleDescriptions.description: We based our application on a navigation map with two tasks, from which we created a low-fidelity prototype using Balsamiq and designed the experiment.

rightBubbleDescriptions.title: Video Prototype
rightBubbleDescriptions.description: The project ended with a video showing how a person could use our application to attend an event through our system.

designConcept: I spent two years as a full stack developer working on Niipy, a platform that allows businesses to advertise across multiple social media channels while managing them from a single platform.

leftBubbleDescriptions.title: Working in team
leftBubbleDescriptions.description: I was part of a team using the agile methodology. My role was to transfer prototypes to the browser side using various front-end frameworks and ensure their connection to the back-end.

rightBubbleDescriptions.title: My Contributions
rightBubbleDescriptions.description: I needed to integrate several API services, including Google Authentication, Google Places and Google My Business. The AWS architecture supporting the development hosted several Docker machines, which in turn hosted the services. I performed code reviews and tested the code before deploying it to production.

designConcept: Rosterbook is the first app that connects FIP and CSI registered players with sports managers for sports negotiations and player career history.

leftBubbleDescriptions.title: Big Data Collection
leftBubbleDescriptions.description: I spent 3 months gathering information, designing, learning and coding the frontend and backend of the application all by myself. My brother helped me with the data collection and we managed to have the most complete data set of all the minor basketball teams in Italy.

leftBubbleDescriptions.title: Connecting Players and Managers
leftBubbleDescriptions.description: The app allows players to create a CV of their sporting career. The profiles are then indexed and displayed through filtered searches, making it easier for sports managers and coaches to find and contact players.

rightBubbleDescriptions.title: Launch to the market
rightBubbleDescriptions.description: The app had 5,000 downloads from basketball players in 2 months with more than 3,000 registered profiles. The requests were increasing and I could not do all the work myself and we did not have enough resources to keep the project going. It was a great learning experience, both technically and business wise. The application is no longer available, but who knows if it will come back in the future üòÉ

designConcept: Run-it is a voice-activated wearable projector for runners, offering path selection and personalization with landmarks and points of interest, real-time running data, route issue reporting, map sharing, and access to favorite routes and run statistics.
titleDetails: Design a new navigation system for runners

leftBubbleDescriptions.title: User Interviews
leftBubbleDescriptions.description: To gather information about navigation, we interviewed 10 runners in Paris and asked them to describe their navigation experiences and the problems they encountered.

leftBubbleDescriptions.title: Current and Future Scenarios
leftBubbleDescriptions.description: We created a current scenario based on the interviews and a future scenario based on the current scenario and the latest technology available in December 2023.

rightBubbleDescriptions.title: Storyboard
rightBubbleDescriptions.description: Given the future scenario, we created a storyboard to show how the product would be used in the future. The storyboard included 8 breakpoints and 3 personas that needed to interact with each other.

rightBubbleDescriptions.title: Prototyping and Filming
rightBubbleDescriptions.description: We iterated 3 times on our first prototype, which was made with transparent paper and markers. We made a video based on our future scenario and had our video reviewed by other groups who helped us improve our design.

designConcept: From the original Tune Crafter project, we decided to create an AR version of the application to allow users to play music with tangibles and AR.
titleDetails: Playing music with tangibles and AR

leftBubbleDescriptions.title: Unity and Vuforia
leftBubbleDescriptions.description: The application was built using Unity and Vuforia. We used the Vuforia library to recognize the objects and the Unity library to create the interactions.

leftBubbleDescriptions.title: Tangibles
leftBubbleDescriptions.description: To create the design of the tablet, we observed how DJs actually play the console and tried to make it easier for them to play with our tangibles.

rightBubbleDescriptions.title: Further Development
rightBubbleDescriptions.description: The result of the project was the creation of an Android application that allows the user to view and interact with physical objects through the camera. Further development could include bringing this application to AR glasses and headsets to improve the user experience.

designConcept: I Love Music is a composition of simple notes in the shape of a heart, representing my love for music in all it's forms. Everything including the design iterations, drawing, printing and assembling was done by me.

leftBubbleDescriptions.title: Drawing and Printing
leftBubbleDescriptions.description: Autocad Fusion 360 was used to design the 3D shapes. Printing was done on Prusa 3D printers using PHA filaments, which are produced and consumed by bacteria and are therefore more sustainable than PLA.

leftBubbleDescriptions.title: Prototyping and Testing
leftBubbleDescriptions.description: The difficulty of the project lay in the constraints of the project. 6 iterations of design and testing were required to improve the final product.

rightBubbleDescriptions.title: Mass production
rightBubbleDescriptions.description: Once the design had been finalized, a total of 50 pieces were printed using optimization methods to maximize efficiency and minimize production time.

rightBubbleDescriptions.title: Final product
rightBubbleDescriptions.description: Each piece could be connected to the others in seven ways. The final project was 50 pieces connected together to form a hearth shape, representing my love for music.
